The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show.

The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show. The union's recent actions have sparked a heated debate about the future of healthcare in the United Kingdom, raising questions about the role of medical professionals in shaping health policies.

According to critics, the refusal by the union to engage in constructive dialogue is hindering efforts to streamline processes, enhance patient satisfaction, and ultimately improve health outcomes. They argue that the union's stance is primarily driven by self-interest, rather than the welfare of patients.

The union, however, has denied these allegations, maintaining that their primary concern is the welfare of both patients and doctors. They argue that they are being unfairly targeted and scapegoated for larger systemic issues within the NHS.

original: The investment is backed by nearly £15m from the Welsh government with production due to start in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart said the deal would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years". "In a climate of stiff global competitiveness, we have been actively seeking to win a share of this investment for Wales," she said. "Ford's decision to manufacture its new innovative engine here in Wales is a tribute to the reputation of the local management team and the quality and loyalty of the Welsh workforce," she added. The Ford Bridgend plant opened in 1980 and has fought fierce competition to win successive investments in the past worth more than £2.8bn. The company has said its presence supports around 10,000 jobs in south Wales, with 1,860 employed at the plant itself. Ford said its presence supports about 10,000 jobs in south Wales, including 1,860 at the plant. Technicians from Essex and Germany collaborated on the design and development of a new fuel-efficient engine range.

The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both under investigation.

The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates for the upcoming general elections in a move that is being seen as a strategic decision to maintain stability and continuity within the party. This endorsement is expected to boost party morale and also bolster the chances of the party securing its hold in the constituencies they currently represent.

A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both of whom are under scrutiny for alleged financial discrepancies. The two MPs have been at the center of a controversy that has cast a shadow on the integrity of the party. The decision on their candidacy will be a crucial one as it would signal the party's stand on issues of financial impropriety.

Party insiders are hopeful that the decision will be in favor of the party's reputation and public trust. The upcoming elections will be pivotal in testing the party's resilience amidst these challenges.

original: Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan said people were "rightly furious it appears lessons are not being learnt". Thames Water has said a "full investigation" will take place "to reduce the risk of further disruption". Mr Khan said the "huge damage" caused was "a devastating thing to happen in the run-up to Christmas". "It is right that Thames Water have launched a full investigation, and residents and business must now get full compensation," he said. Director Bob Collington told the BBC the firm had spent "about Â£1bn a year upgrading our network" but "clearly the events of the last few weeks point to the fact that we need to do even more". Some business owners have accused the company of "incompetence" over the floods. Gonen Ozer, who owns two businesses in Stoke Newington, said the mains had been leaking for several days but the water firm had only "patched it up temporarily". "I can only describe Thames Water's attitude as reckless, irresponsible and totally unprofessional", he said. Emily Oliphant was in her Blackheath

original:
Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and her ten-year-old daughter, Lauren Thornton. The pair were found dead on a boat owned by Eteson, moored on Lake Windermere in April 2013. It's alleged that their untimely deaths were the result of carbon monoxide poisoning, resulting from a faulty generator Eteson had reportedly installed on the boat.

The prosecution states that Eteson, a gas fitter by trade, had a duty of care towards his partner and her daughter and failed to meet it. They argue that it was his negligence in failing to ensure that the generator was safe that led directly to the tragic deaths. 

Eteson denies the charges, his defense team plans to argue that the deaths were a tragic accident. The trial is expected to last for several weeks, with the outcome having potential legal implications for boat owners nationwide.

original:
Spencer Flower claimed his involvement with a social housing company was not relevant to a debate in 2013 over the future of housing in east Dorset. He defended his actions amid allegations of a conflict of interest. Flower, a member of the Dorset County Council, found himself at the center of controversy when it was revealed that he held a significant stake in a housing company involved in projects in the area.

Critics argued that Flower's affiliation with the company created a conflict between his private interests and his public duties. But Flower insisted that his business interests did not affect his participation in the debate and decision-making process. He stated that he had always been transparent about his business affiliations and had refrained from participating in matters where there might be a conflict.

This incident has ignited a conversation about the need for stricter rules around the disclosure of council members' business interests. It has also raised questions about how local government decisions are made and the extent to which personal interests may influence these decisions.

original:
PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary. The incident, which took place last year, has come to light this week after a disciplinary hearing found her guilty of gross misconduct.

Tilley, a police officer with over ten years of service, confessed to travelling without a valid ticket and subsequently providing false information during the formal investigation. This incident has resulted in her dismissal from the Avon and Somerset Police Department.

The panel, chaired by independent legal adviser, Jane Jones, concluded that Tilley's actions were deliberate and constituted a serious breach of the Standards of Professional Behaviour. The decision to dismiss her was unanimous, reflecting the severity of her misconduct. 

In a statement, Tilley expressed remorse for her actions and acknowledged the self-inflicted end of her career. The incident serves as a crucial reminder that police officers, like all individuals, are expected to uphold the law at all times.

original: Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. But a disciplinary panel ruled contact with the pupil was probably made and her conduct had been "unacceptable". On Thursday, the Education Workforce Council imposed the suspension, saying: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again." Mrs Hungerford admitted shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager as he listened to rap music in her classroom - but always denied hitting his head. She was cleared, on appeal, of a criminal charge for assaulting the pupil during a maths lesson for those with learning difficulties. But in November, a disciplinary panel found, on the balance of probabilities, she had made physical conduct with the pupil on the head or hand. The panel found she had "acted in an inappropriate way" and ruled it was professional misconduct. During the hearing,

original: Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those from the Gaelic Irish background, those without the party political background". Mr Ó Muilleoir said he hoped the meeting would happen soon. "It's a positive move," he said. "Anything that encourages dialogue, that encourages conversations, that encourages increased understanding has to be positive." Stormont's parties have "paused" talks to strike a deal to form an executive until after Easter. The parties have yet to find a deal almost six weeks after the assembly election. One of Sinn Féin's key priorities in the talks is a guarantee that an Irish Language Act will be enacted. In February, Arlene Foster said the DUP would never agree to an Irish Language Act. But she has now said she would meet with "people who genuinely love the Irish language and don't want to use it as a political weapon". Mr Museveni's supporters said his opponents had failed to offer any chance of progress. But Mr Besigye, who is under house arrest, said the results were a "sham", calling on the international community to reject them. "We have just witnessed what must be the most fraudulent electoral process in Uganda," he said in a statement. original: An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for it to date. The Welsh Government is seeking legal advice over recovering the outstanding debt, a letter says. The company says talks are ongoing. It is not known how much the rent is worth. Mr Dickinson previously told BBC Wales that his firm was losing millions of pounds because of a dispute over landing rights. The Iron Maiden front-man set up Cardiff Aviation in 2012 at RAF St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, leasing a hangar called Twin Peaks from the Welsh Government. original: The ban was backed by local authorities in Urumqi, state media reported. The move is the latest in a campaign against Islamic clothing and symbols in the mainly Muslim region. China's government has blamed Uighur militants for several recent attacks - but activists say the violence has been fuelled by Chinese repression. The Uighurs traditionally practice a moderate form of Islam. Recently, though, the influence of stricter forms of the faith from the Gulf and Pakistan has led to more women covering their faces. According to the BBC's Asia Pacific editor, Charles Scanlon, the Chinese authorities regard wearing an Islamic face veil as an act of defiance at a time of growing violence in the region. In August this year, the northern city of Karamay banned men with long beards from boarding buses. Some experts believe such restrictions could backfire at a time when many Uighurs believe their culture is under attack. James Leibold, an expert on China's ethnic
variant_1: Local authorities in Urumqi supported the ban, according to state media reports. This action is part of an ongoing campaign targeting Islamic attire and symbols in the predominantly Muslim region. The Chinese government has accused Uighur militants of several recent attacks, though activists argue that Chinese repression has fueled the violence. Traditionally, Uighurs follow a moderate form of Islam, but recently stricter interpretations from the Gulf and Pakistan have led to more women covering their faces. BBC Asia Pacific editor Charles Scanlon notes that Chinese officials view wearing an Islamic face veil as a form of defiance amid rising regional violence. In August, Karamay city prohibited men with long beards from boarding buses. Some experts warn these measures might backfire, as many Uighurs feel their culture is being threatened. James Leibold, a specialist in China's ethnic issues, has commented on this situation.

original: The button would give Google Search users the option to purchase without needing to visit a separate website. The company's chief business officer, Omid Kordestani, said he wanted to reduce "friction" for users so they buy more things online. Google faces significant competition from Amazon, where many people now begin their search to buy products. "There's going to be a buy button. It's going to be imminent," said Mr Kordestani on stage at the Code Conference in California on Wednesday. The change would make it easier for shoppers to buy products featured in its shopping ads that appear alongside search results. Mr Kordestani also noted that about nine out of 10 purchases are still made offline. He added that the number of location-based searches to help users find something close to them had doubled in the past year. Getting users to buy products as a result of searching is a key revenue earner for Google which currently charges retailers a premium to appear in a prominent position on the results page following a relevant search query. "With Google Buy set to only be
variant_1: The button would allow Google Search users to buy items without having to go to a different website. Omid Kordestani, the company's chief business officer, said he aimed to minimize "friction" for users so they would purchase more online. Google is up against strong competition from Amazon, where many people start their product searches. "A buy button is coming soon," Mr. Kordestani announced at the Code Conference in California on Wednesday. This update would simplify the process for shoppers to purchase products shown in shopping ads next to search results. Mr. Kordestani also mentioned that roughly 90% of purchases still happen offline. He added that location-based searches to find nearby items have doubled over the last year. Encouraging users to buy products through search is a major source of revenue for Google, which currently charges retailers a premium for prominent placement on results pages after relevant queries. "With Google Buy about to launch..."

original: But he fancied his video game skills and entered Nissan's GT Academy competition while on a gap year. After beating 90,000 other gamers at racing simulation game Gran Turismo, Jann was offered the chance to train as a professional driver. He's now joining Arden Motorsport to compete in the 2014 GP3 series, which is just two rungs below Formula 1. The 22-year-old from Cardiff has also been taken on by Infiniti Red Bull's driver development programme. Jann says winning GT Academy was a huge shock: "I thought I was pretty good because I could beat my friends on my street, but it was the first time trial I ever entered. "I just wanted to see how I stacked up against people across Europe but I didn't expect to win. No way I thought that!" Since 2011 he has competed in British GT, Formula 3's European Championship, and a series in New Zealand, but describes the latest step

original: On 30 January 1915, England played Scotland in a charity match organised by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs. The aim of the game had been to recruit sportsmen to Mobbs's World War One battalion. The commemorative match will take place on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club. It will see players from the East Midlands region line up against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while Olney Ladies will face the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs •Born in Northampton in 1882 • He played his early career in Olney and became captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907 •Selected for England in 1909, he scored a try on his debut against Australia and went on to win seven caps •He went from private to battalion commander. fighting in Loos, Somme, Arras and Messines •Mentioned in Despatches twice, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Order •He died while charging a German machine gun during the battle of Passchendale on 31 July 1917 Having retired from rugby in 1913 aged 30, Mobbs was refused an officer's commission when war broke out because of his
variant_1: On January 30, 1915, England faced Scotland in a charity rugby match organized by Edgar Mobbs, a former England international and Northampton Saints captain. The match aimed to recruit athletes for Mobbs's World War One battalion. A commemorative game is scheduled for January 24, 2015, at Olney Rugby Club, featuring East Midlands players against the 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, with Olney Ladies playing the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs was born in Northampton in 1882, started his career in Olney, captained Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907, debuted for England in 1909 scoring a try against Australia, earned seven caps, rose from private to battalion commander, fought in major battles, was twice Mentioned in Despatches, received the Distinguished Service Order, and died charging a German machine gun at Passchendaele on July 31, 1917. He retired from rugby in 1913 at age 30 and was denied an officer's commission at the war's start due to his...

original: The Halle Orchestra wants to open a school in Stoke-on-Trent in 2020, for both primary and secondary pupils. The orchestra will work with an academy trust in setting up the school. John Summers, chief executive of the orchestra, said the project would use music to "raise aspirations" across other academic subjects. The school, proposed with the City Learning Trust, would be part of the free schools programme - and approval for its opening depends on the Department for Education. But the orchestra wants to open the school in September 2020, for seven to 19-year-olds, with the promise of masterclasses from musicians, access to concerts and artists in residence. The intention is for students to spend 40% of their time in specialist music classes, working with the Halle Choir, The Halle Youth Orchestra and Halle for Youth. "The Halle has a huge amount of expertise and experience in working at high level performance, both in terms of instrumental coaching and choral training," said John Summers, chief executive

John Summers highlighted the orchestra's extensive expertise in high-level performance, including instrumental coaching and choral training.

Summers highlighted the orchestra's considerable expertise in high-level instrumental coaching and choral training.

original:
The 31-year-old tweeted she was turned away from a black cab and told to "find an immigrant" to give her a ride. This alarming incident has sparked a heated conversation on social media about racial bias and discrimination within the transportation industry. The woman, who requested to remain anonymous, shared her shock and disappointment regarding the incident, which took place in Central London on Friday evening.
 
Promoting a wave of outrage and empathy, the tweet has been retweeted over 1,000 times, with many users expressing disgust at the cab driver's blatant display of discrimination. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association, upon learning about the incident, has vowed to investigate the matter, reiterating that such behaviour is completely contrary to their code of conduct. This incident underpins the persistent issue of racial discrimination that continues to plague our society, reminding us of the urgency to address and rectify it. It's a stark reminder that despite strides made in promoting equality, there remains much work to be done.

original: The were 37 crimes recorded in Cromer over the weekend - including the rape of a teenager - with residents linking them to a group of travellers. Suffolk Constabulary said it warned Norfolk Police about the group ahead of its arrival on Friday. Norfolk confirmed it was made aware and said it was reviewing its response. Suffolk officers said they told their Norfolk colleagues about the group after it was issued with a local authority notice to leave Lowestoft on Friday afternoon. The notice had been served after a number of incidents of disturbance in the town. Norfolk confirmed it had been told but said there was "no intelligence to suggest where the group was heading". On Friday, a woman in her late teens was raped at a bus stop in Cadogan Road, near the seafront. Norfolk Police said there was evidence to suggest it could have been linked to the disorder in the town. One man was arrested and released under investigation in connection with the rape. No other arrests have been made. On Saturday night, a BBC reporter was told by a taxi driver that "travellers are rampaging the town",

original: A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch initial findings found the signaller believed there was enough space for both trains on the platform. About 35 people were injured. Read more on this story as it develops throughout the day on our Local Live pages The report said: "Allowing trains to share a platform is known as permissive working, and is allowed for passenger trains using platform six. "The signaller could see the rear of the train from the signal box window and estimated there was enough room for the moving train to fit on the platform. This was not the case." One of the trains was moved to platform six due to passenger lifts being closed for maintenance on alternative platforms, the report said. While approaching Plymouth, the moving train accelerated to about 21 mph and went through a relatively tight, left-hand curve. That is when the driver saw the rear of the stationary train on platform six and was surprised to see it so close to the west end of the platform.

The Rail Accident Investigation Branch's initial findings found the signaller believed there was enough space for both trains on the platform. Around 35 people were injured. Follow updates on this story throughout the day on our Local Live pages. The report said permissive working, which allows passenger trains to share platform six, was allowed. The signaller, who could see the rear of the train from the signal box window, estimated there was enough room for the moving train to fit on the platform, but this was not the case. One train was moved to platform six due to passenger lifts being closed for maintenance on other platforms. As the moving train approached Plymouth, it accelerated to about 21 mph and went through a relatively tight left-hand curve. The driver saw the rear of the stationary train on platform six and was surprised to see it so close to the west end of the platform.

That amount is equivalent to the combined economies of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain and the United Kingdom, the report by the Institute for Economic and Peace (IEP) stated. The report, unveiling the staggering cost of violence globally, stated that the economic impact of violence on the world economy in 2022 was $14.96 trillion. This figure does not merely represent the direct costs of violence, but also incorporates the additional economic activity that would have transpired if these resources had been directed towards more beneficial ends.

The IEP explained that the cost of violence equates to 11.6% of the global gross domestic product (GDP), or $1,998 for every person. The highest economic impact was observed in Syria, where the cost of violence is estimated at 60% of its GDP. These figures underline the urgent need for peace and stability to enable sustainable economic development.

The report concluded that fostering peace not only saves lives but is economically prudent. Precious resources can be diverted away from conflict and violence towards positive growth. It is a wake-up call for policymakers to invest in peace building and conflict-resolution

original: The removal of the engines, which have lain idle for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. Savings from the proposal would be invested in making more staff available to crew Fire Rescue Units. But the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) said it would be "dangerous and reckless" to get rid of them permanently. The London Fire Brigade (LFB) has released three plans to make the savings. It insists no stations will close and no firefighters will be forced to leave their jobs. The Brigade said it had continued to meet London-wide attendance time targets while the 13 engines had been out of service. It said that bringing them back would improve response times by about four seconds for the first engine to reach the scene. An alternative proposal has been put forward by London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore, who recommends putting the 13 fire engines back into service but making savings by establishing alternate crewing at
variant_1: Removing the engines, which have been unused for two years, would leave 142 operational vehicles in the capital. The savings from this plan would be used to increase staffing for Fire Rescue Units. However, the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) warned that permanently removing them would be "dangerous and reckless." The London Fire Brigade (LFB) has proposed three plans to achieve the savings, assuring that no stations will close and no firefighters will lose their jobs. The Brigade stated it has maintained London-wide attendance targets despite the 13 engines being out of service. original: The Republican sought to laugh off the comment, which was preceded by the supporter saying: "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims". The comments were made at a campaign rally for Mr Trump in New Hampshire. Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton said his failure to denounce "hateful rhetoric" was "disturbing and wrong". Pointing to his first questioner at the campaign event in Rochester, the billionaire businessman said: "I like this guy." "We have a problem in this country called Muslims," the man said. "We know our current president is one. You know he's not even an American." "We need this question?" Mr Trump said, laughing. "But anyway," the man continued, "we have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Mr Trump failed to clarify that Mr Obama is a Christian American, instead replying that "bad things are happening" and saying he would look into them. Mrs Clinton joined criticism of Mr Trump

original:
The site is believed to contain thousands of copies of a video game called ET The Extra-Terrestrial. A company called Atari made the game in 1982, drawing inspiration from Steven Spielberg's blockbuster of the same name. The site is believed to contain thousands of copies of a video game called ET The Extra-Terrestrial, sealed in a New Mexico landfill. The game's lackluster reception and commercial failure famously led Atari to bury unsold and returned copies, marking a notorious chapter in video gaming history.

Atari, once a giant in the gaming industry, was forced to bury approximately 700,000 cartridges in the Alamogordo landfill following the video game crash of 1983. The ET game earned a reputation as one of the worst games ever due to its confusing gameplay and poor graphics. Its failure, coupled with a general oversaturation of the market, contributed significantly to Atari's financial downfall.

The buried cartridges were unearthed in 2014, confirming rumors that have circulated for years. Now a symbol of the volatile boom and bust cycle in the gaming industry, the ET game serves as a fascinating relic of video gaming's

original: The number given for the current account customers hit by the fraud is fewer than half of the 20,000 initially reported to have been affected. Personal data "was not compromised" in the attack, and all accounts affected had been refunded, the bank said. Tesco Bank has said it was hit by "a systematic, sophisticated attack" at the weekend. "We've now refunded all customer accounts affected by fraud and lifted the suspension of online debit transactions so that customers can use their accounts as normal," said chief executive Benny Higgins. Current account customers had been blocked from making online payments using their debit card since Sunday, an action the bank said it had taken "to prevent criminal activity". "We'd again like to apologise for the worry and inconvenience this issue has caused," said Mr Higgins. Mr Higgins said the bank knew "exactly" the nature of the attack, but could not say more because it was part of a criminal investigation. The National

original:
Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, a minimum dress code, and proof of right to work in the UK, from taxi drivers in an effort to improve services and enhance safety for passengers. This comes as an initiative to address a number of issues that have been raised by passengers and the taxi industry.

The proposed tests would be an addition to the already rigorous requirements set by the TfL for taxi drivers, including a topographical test and a medical check. The English language test is aimed to ensure that drivers can effectively communicate with passengers, while the map-reading assessment is designed to improve navigational skills. The introduction of a minimum dress code is to maintain a professional image, whereas the proof of right to work in the UK is a measure to comply with immigration laws.

These changes are expected to raise the standard of service provided by taxi drivers in London and enhance passengers' overall experience. The consultation is due to commence in the coming weeks and will last for three months.

This initiative responds to concerns raised by passengers and the taxi sector.

original: The walkout is in protest over the dismissal of two nurses involved in a violent struggle with a patient. Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton were sacked from City Hospital last week, triggering a wave of outrage among their colleagues. The nurses' union argues that the two were merely defending themselves against an aggressive patient, who is known to have a history of violent behavior and mental health issues. They claim that the hospital's management has failed to provide adequate security or safeguards for its staff against such incidents. This dismissal, they contend, sets a dangerous precedent and underscores a lack of support for the staff's safety. The walkout has significantly impacted the hospital operations with many non-emergency procedures being delayed. The management is currently in talks with the nurses' union, hoping to resolve the situation quickly. However, the protesting nurses are firm on their stand and demand a full investigation into the incident before they return to work. They insist that their dismissal was unjust and the administration should address their concerns over workplace safety.

original: The retailer claims the plans for Chippenham would create 1,000 jobs and bring Â£31m into the economy each year. However, of the five candidates vying to become the area's MP, one is totally against it and three admit to having questions over the proposed site. Petitions for and against have been signed by thousands of people locally. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan said she could see both sides, but believes the consultation - which has now ended - was inadequate for something that is "dramatically going to change the town forever". The application for the 72,000 sq m regional centre is yet to be discussed by Wiltshire Council, but the five candidates gave their views during an election debate recorded for broadcast by BBC Wiltshire. Andy Newman, for Labour, said he was in support of the development and had been assured it would bring in 700 permanent skilled jobs and would "push up wages in the area". In contrast,

original: The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the collection. The aim is for the charity to eventually become self sufficient. Other powers such as listing buildings will remain government funded. The new official body, which will also advise on planning, has a working name of the National Heritage Protection Service. The new charity will still be called English Heritage and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection - which include London's Kenwood House, and Charles Darwin's home in Kent - will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will be tapered down from 2015 eventually to nothing, meaning it will have more freedom than now to generate income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Some of the £80m awarded by the government will help to set up the charity so it will be fully operational by
variant_1: The newly formed charity will oversee the National Heritage Collection, which features Stonehenge and Dover Castle. Currently, the government provides £22 million annually for the collection. The goal is for the charity to become financially independent over time. Other responsibilities, such as building listings, will continue to be government-funded. This new official organization, also responsible for planning advice, is tentatively named the National Heritage Protection Service. The charity will retain the name English Heritage, and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection—including London's Kenwood House and Charles Darwin's residence in Kent—will stay publicly owned. Government funding for the charity will be gradually reduced starting in 2015 until it ceases, allowing the charity greater freedom to earn revenue through commercial ventures and donations. Part of the £80 million granted by the government will support the charity's establishment to ensure it is fully operational by then.
variant_2: The National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle, will be managed by a new charity. The government currently allocates £22 million each year to support the collection. The charity aims to become self-sustaining eventually. Government funding will continue for other functions like building listings. The new body, provisionally called the National Heritage Protection Service, will also provide planning advice. The charity will keep the name English Heritage, and the 420 sites in the collection—such as Kenwood House in London and Charles Darwin's home in Kent—will remain publicly owned. Government funding will be phased out from 2015, giving the charity more autonomy to generate income from commercial activities and donations. An £80 million government grant will help establish the charity so it can operate fully by that time.
variant_3: A new charity will take charge of the National Heritage Collection, which comprises Stonehenge and Dover Castle. original:
Among them was a 17-year-old stopped at Sydney airport a fortnight ago, said Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr Dutton said there were increasing concerns about the number of Australian teenagers being radicalized and trying to join extremist groups overseas. The 17-year-old, whose identity has been withheld due to privacy laws, was stopped under Operation Rampart, a joint initiative by the Australian Border Force and the Australian Federal Police, aimed at identifying and deterring individuals from travelling overseas to participate in hostile activities. 

Mr. Dutton warned that extremist groups were actively targeting vulnerable young Australians online, leveraging their sense of isolation or grievances to push radical ideologies. The incident underscores the ongoing threat of homegrown extremism, in a country that has largely been insulated from the global scourge of terrorism.

The Minister urged parents and guardians to keep a vigilant eye on the online activities of their children, raising awareness of the risks associated with radicalisation. He also assured the public that the Government is committed to doing everything in its power to protect Australians from such threats.

original:
Kevin Mcleod's body was found in Wick harbour in February 1997. The 24-year-old's death was treated as accidental, but recent developments have urged a reconsideration of the case. The Mcleod family has long suspected foul play, alleging a cover-up by the local police force.

The Scottish Police Authority (SPA) has now decided to reopen the case, following numerous appeals by the family and the emergence of new evidence. A fresh autopsy report suggests that Mcleod could have suffered internal injuries before drowning, contradicting the initial findings of accidental death by drowning.

The Mcleod family's relentless pursuit for justice and the new autopsy findings have sparked a nationwide conversation about accountability and transparency in law enforcement agencies.

The SPA has expressed its commitment to a comprehensive review of the case. They hope their efforts will provide the family with the answers they have sought for over two decades and potentially bring to light any misconduct or negligence that may have occurred.

original:
Disguised as police, they broke through a fence on Monday evening and broke into the cargo of a Swiss-bound plane to take the stash of precious gems worth millions of dollars. This audacious heist occurred at the Brussels International Airport, shocking authorities and the global community alike. 

The robbers, wearing what appeared to be police uniforms and driving vehicles outfitted with blue flashing lights, pulled off the daring heist with military precision. They moved quickly, using high-powered tools to cut through the perimeter fence, avoiding detection and leaving no one injured. 

The swift and professional operation took the thieves less than twenty minutes, from breach to escape, leaving authorities stunned and empty-handed. The gems were en route from Antwerp, the world's diamond trading hub, to Switzerland when they were intercepted. 

The incident has raised serious concerns about the security of valuable cargo transported by air. Investigations are currently underway, with Interpol and local authorities working together to bring these audacious robbers to justice.

original:
As with last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 notified bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in Belfast during the upcoming annual 12th July demonstrations. This ruling, confirmed by the Parades Commission, follows an unsuccessful appeal by the Carrick Hill Residents Association, who had requested that no loyalist marches be allowed past the Catholic church. 

The decision is seen as a way to avoid clashes and maintain social harmony, following a history of sectarian unrest associated with the parade, which commemorates the 1690 Battle of the Boyne. As part of the ruling, only a single drumbeat will be played by the bands while passing the contentious area. 

Furthermore, the Commission has stipulated that no supporters will be allowed to accompany the march past the church. Both the Orangemen and the residents have been encouraged to continue dialogue to ensure the peaceful passing of the parade.

original: Media playback is not supported on this device Fraser, the world number 90, hit nine birdies to finish with an eight under par 63, three shots ahead of the field. More than half of the men's world's top 10 pulled out of competing at Rio 2016, citing the Zika virus. Briton Justin Rose, one of a group on four under, hit the first ever Olympic hole-in-one on the par-three fourth. "There is always an element of luck but you could chalk it up as a good hole-in-one," said Rose. "I won a car that time [his last hole-in-one] but this is definitely better, better bragging rights. When you are the first to do something no one can take that away from you. That was definitely a cool moment." Newly crowned Open champion Henrik Stenson is tied for second with Canada's Graham Delaet on five under. Rose is one of five men tied for fourth on four under; along with Belgium's Thomas Pieters, Gregory Bourdy of France, Alex Cejka of Germany and Spain's Rafael Cabrera Bello. Danny Willett, who became the first British winner of the Masters for 20 years in April, finished

original:
Rachel Miller has paid "brokers" up to £7,500 a time to free sex slaves. She travelled to parts of southern Asia, risking her life on an audacious mission to liberate women and children ensnared in the brutal world of human trafficking. 

This bold British woman, moved by the horrific stories of sexual exploitation, chose to dedicate her life to combat this heinous crime. Operating under constant danger, she put her safety on the line to negotiate with ruthless traffickers. 

Her mission, although fraught with peril, has led to the successful rescue of hundreds of victims. Each individual saved is a testament to Miller's courage and perseverance in the face of a grotesque industry that abuses the vulnerable.

Despite the risks, Miller continues her tireless work, raising awareness about human trafficking, and urging global authorities to intensify their efforts to end this modern-day slavery. This courageous woman's story is a powerful reminder that one person's determination can indeed make a world of difference.

original: Unemployment fell to 1.69 million between January and March, down 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate remained at 5.1%, the ONS said. There were 31.58 million people in work, up 44,000 from the previous quarter. That took the employment rate to a record high of 74.2%. But the number of job vacancies dropped by 18,000 to 745,000, the ONS added, marking the first fall for almost a year. David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, said: "The employment rate has hit another record high, but this time the increase is quite modest. "With unemployment very little changed, that is further evidence the jobs market could be cooling off." Average earnings including bonuses rose 2% from a year earlier, up from 1.9% in the three months to February. The ONS said the timing of bonuses this year had affected the rise in total earnings. Evha Jannath, 11, was on a school trip on Tuesday when she fell from a circular boat on Splash Canyon at Drayton Manor Theme Park. A tragic incident unfolded on Tuesday when Evha Jannath, an 11-year-old girl, fell from a circular boat on Splash Canyon during a school trip at Drayton Manor Theme Park. The Bright Start Academy pupil from Leicester was airlifted to Birmingham Children's Hospital, but unfortunately succumbed to her injuries. 

The incident has sent shockwaves through the community, and has put a spotlight on safety measures in amusement parks. Jannath was on a water ride at the park, which is a popular attraction for families and school groups. 

Her school released a statement expressing their grief over the tragic loss of a promising student and extended their condolences to her family. Drayton Manor Theme Park is currently closed for investigations, with park officials working closely with safety experts and local authorities to determine the exact circumstances that led to this terrible event. The incident has sparked a nationwide conversation about the adequacy of current amusement park safety standards.

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) has stated that blood group O negative is crucial, as it can be used for patients with other blood types, making it especially valuable in emergency situations. NHSBT, the agency responsible for ensuring a safe and sufficient supply of blood in the UK, is currently facing an urgent appeal for O negative donors to come forward following a sharp decrease in donations.

According to the NHSBT, the reserves of O negative blood have fallen below the preferred minimum of three days' worth. The group A & O negative are universal donors, and their blood can be used in any patient, making it a vital resource in urgent or emergency care when there may not be time to determine a patient's blood group.

The interactive display can replicate the phone's touch screen, a full-size computer keyboard or even piano keys. The laser projector can also be used to transfer various interfaces onto tabletops, walls, or even your own hand. 

This groundbreaking technology is paving the way for a new era of interactivity, propelling us towards a future where physical devices may become obsolete. The practical applications are endless, from providing musicians with portable, easily customizable instruments to offering a more immersive and flexible workspace for professionals.

The laser projector works by emitting a grid of infrared beams. When the user interacts with the projected interface, the beams are interrupted, and the system can calculate the exact location of the interaction. For instance, each faux piano key or button pressed on a projected keyboard can correspond to a specific note or command.

original: The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, once linked to smuggling, was visited by Treasure Island author Robert Louis Stevenson. Developer PegasusLife wants to replace it with 74 pensioner flats. Opponents insist the unlisted building is historically significant and an influx of elderly residents would put pressure on services in the village. The plans to be considered by the National Park Authority (NPA) are open for consultation until early January. Originally named, Glasshayes House, the mansion house on the edge of Lyndhurst was built in the early 19th Century as a private home for railway entrepreneur Charles Castleman. Along with Louis Stevenson, its notable historical guests included Lord Carnarvon of Highclere Castle. It later became the Grand Hotel, and then the Lyndhurst Park Hotel. PegasusLife plans to replace it with 74 "age restricted ... high quality assisted living" apartments for which it said there was "a very high need" for, along with 12 holiday lets. Its proposal

original: The firm is accused of giving large donations to non-profit foundations operated by Choi Soon-sil, a close confidante of Ms Park. The donations were allegedly given in exchange for political support of a controversial merger. Ms Choi has been charged with coercion and attempted fraud. According to South Korea's Yonhap news agency, Choi Gee-sung, a Samsung vice chairman, and Chang Choong-ki, a president at the group, were being interviewed on Monday by special prosecutors about the corruption allegations. It was reported the pair were being treated as witnesses, rather than being suspected of any wrongdoing. The claims circle around a merger between the electronics giant's construction arm, Samsung C&T, and an affiliate firm, Cheil Industries. The deal went through despite significant opposition from shareholders, who said it would hurt minority shareholders while benefiting the family of Samsung's group owner Lee Kun-hee. South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), which owns stakes in both companies, sealed the deal by voting in favour of it and the head of the NPS has since been arrested. But prosecutors also allege that Samsung gave â‚¬2.8m euros ($3.1m; Â£2.5m) to a company
variant_1: The company stands accused of making substantial donations to non-profit foundations managed by Choi Soon-sil, a close associate of Ms. Park. These donations were allegedly made in return for political backing of a contentious merger. Ms. Choi faces charges of coercion and attempted fraud. According to South Korea's Yonhap news agency, Samsung vice chairman Choi Gee-sung and group president Chang Choong-ki were interviewed by special prosecutors on Monday regarding corruption allegations. Reports indicate they were treated as witnesses, not suspects. The allegations revolve around a merger between Samsung's construction division, Samsung C&T, and its affiliate, Cheil Industries. Despite strong opposition from shareholders who claimed the deal would harm minority shareholders and benefit Samsung group owner Lee Kun-hee's family, the merger proceeded. South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), a stakeholder in both firms, approved the deal, and its head has been arrested. Prosecutors also claim Samsung donated €2.8 million ($3.1 million; £2.5 million) to a company.

original:
The ban was backed by local authorities in Urumqi, state media reported. The move is the latest in a campaign against Islamic clothing and symbols in the region. The regulation has stirred international controversy, with human rights advocates voicing their concerns over the potential infringement on individual religious freedoms. 

The local government in Urumqi, the capital city of Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, has argued that the ban seeks to counteract extremism and maintain social harmony. They insist it is not an attempt to suppress the Islamic faith, but rather a measure to prevent the spread of radical ideologies. The ban includes items such as the burqa, a full-body veil worn by some Muslim women, and "jilbabs," outer garments covering the body.

Critics, however, argue that the ban is a symptom of the broader issue of religious discrimination, particularly against the Uyghur Muslim minority. They warn against the potential for increased social alienation and unrest as a result of such measures
variant_1: Local authorities in Urumqi supported the ban, according to state media reports. This action is part of an ongoing campaign targeting Islamic attire and symbols in the area. The regulation has sparked global debate, with human rights groups expressing worries about possible violations of religious freedoms. The Urumqi local government, in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region's capital, claims the ban aims to combat extremism and promote social stability. They emphasize it is not intended to suppress Islam but to stop radical ideology from spreading. The ban covers items like the burqa, a full-body veil worn by some Muslim women, and jilbabs, which are outer garments. original: The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. original: Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cess pit at her house in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016. She had not been seen since 11 April. Ian Stewart, her fiance, denies murder. Edward Farmer initially told St Albans Crown Court he saw her in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June, but later admitted the sighting could have been weeks earlier. The jury heard he claimed to have seen Ms Bailey on Charlotte Street, near to her holiday home in the town, "driving what looked to be a Range Rover or that type of 4x4, a dark colour". He said Ms Bailey was by herself, despite defence claims she had been kidnapped by two violent men who had taken her to Broadstairs. When questioned about the date of the alleged sighting, Mr Farmer said it was "about five, maybe six weeks prior to the police interview [on 13 July]". Ms Bailey

original: A report from British Marine, which represents the leisure, superyacht and small commercial marine industry, said superyacht revenues for the year to date have been skyrocketing. Amid the ongoing pandemic, the superyacht sector is seeing unprecedented growth, demonstrating a 24% increase in revenues compared to the previous year. The luxury sector is experiencing a significant boom, fueled by a surge in demand from high-net-worth individuals seeking safe, social-distanced leisure options. Despite economic uncertainties, the industry has shown resilience, with an increasing number of new build orders and charter bookings. The report also highlights the UK's growing prominence in the global superyacht market, with the country's highly skilled workforce and exceptional craftsmanship being key drivers for the industry's success. This surge showcases the strength and adaptability of the marine industry, even amidst challenging times, contributing significantly to the nation's economy while upholding the highest levels of luxury and exclusivity.

original: Ben Butler met a psychologist in 2004 after assaulting a man in a nightclub. Dr Tim Green wrote Mr Butler found it "difficult to control his violence when he felt humiliated" and "historically would become angry and punch people". The 36-year-old denies murdering six-year-old Ellie at their home in Sutton, south west London, in October 2013. Dr Green interviewed Mr Butler over four hours after he pleaded guilty to assaulting a man in Kingston upon Thames 12 years ago, the Old Bailey heard. Prosecutor Ed Brown QC read sections of the report in which Dr Green noted Mr Butler was "co-operative" and answered questions "frankly". Dr Green wrote: "He stated that he had in the past hoped that situations might present themselves where he could engage in violence. "He believed that violence could help him improve his mood when he was upset. Historically he would become angry and punch people. "He was adamant he had never hit anybody without a reason. He also said at times

original: The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, once linked to smuggling, was visited by Treasure Island author Robert Louis Stevenson. Developer PegasusLife wants to replace it with a modern, state-of-the-art retirement complex. The proposal includes 74 apartments and a host of luxurious amenities for residents to enjoy. However, the plan has sparked widespread controversy among local residents and historians, due to the hotel's iconic status and its cultural importance as a former haunt of Stevenson. They argue that the building holds significant historic value and should be preserved rather than demolished. The hotel, which has stood empty since 2014, was reportedly a hub for smugglers in the 18th century, and it is claimed Stevenson, famed for his adventure novels, stayed there while writing 'Treasure Island'. Despite the backlash, PegasusLife maintains that their proposal will bring a much-needed boost to the local economy through job creation and increased tourism. The final decision is awaited from the local council.

The building, empty since 2014, was once a smuggling hub in the 18th century and is believed to have hosted Stevenson during his writing of Treasure Island. PegasusLife argues the project will boost the local economy through jobs and tourism, while the local council's decision is pending.

original: Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the Southern Uplands on Tuesday. Police said he died late on Wednesday night at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary. George Crosbie, 73, also from Dumfries, died earlier on Wednesday. A third man, Bobby Thomson, 64, remains in hospital. A statement from Mr Stewart's family said: "Our family would like to extend our love and thoughts to the families involved at this very sad and tragic time. "Sincere gratitude and appreciation goes out to all the services involved in the rescue efforts and hospital staff at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary." The men failed to return from a walk in the hills at Durisdeer on Tuesday. Sixteen members of Moffat Mountain Rescue team (MRT) and two search and rescue dogs combed the hills for the men until the early hours of Wednesday. However the search was stood down amid heavy rain, snow, high winds and poor visibility. When it

The 34-year-old midfielder has just finished his latest spell in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. "Having been the backbone of the team for the past season, his contribution has been immense," said the club's spokesperson.

The veteran footballer, who has previously played in European leagues, brought a wealth of experience and skill to Atletico Kolkata. His leadership on and off the field played a pivotal role in guiding the team to the playoffs this season. 

Despite his age, the midfielder demonstrated his physical prowess, maintaining consistency throughout the season. His tactical acumen was particularly praised, giving Atletico Kolkata a crucial edge in key moments of their games.

While the player's future is still under speculation, sources inside the club suggest that they would be keen on retaining him for another season. However, offers from other clubs are also believed to be on the table. As this story develops, fans eagerly await to see where the seasoned footballer will take his talents next.

original: The Starman's swansong, Blackstar, spent a third week at number one, with Best of Bowie, Hunky Dory and Ziggy Stardust all in the Top 10. Adele remained at two, while Suede, who were heavily inspired by Bowie, scored the highest new entry at number six. Rihanna's new album, Anti, did not chart after its release on Thursday. The record was considered ineligible as it was initially given away via the streaming music site Tidal. Official chart company rules state that free downloads do not count towards the top 40. However, the Bajan star did score a new entry in the singles chart. Work, her duet with Drake, made its first appearance at 13 after just 48 hours on sale. The highest new entry, at three, is a dance version of Tracy Chapman's Fast Car by London-based producer Jonas Blue. His tropical-flavoured remake, which features vocals by singer

original: Midfielder Arteta, 32, had a bony spur removed from his left ankle, which the club said has been causing him "significant discomfort" for months. Defender Debuchy, who just returned from three months out with an ankle injury, had an operation on a shoulder he dislocated in the win over Stoke. Boss Arsene Wenger described Debuchy's injury on Sunday as "unbelievable". "It's very unfortunate," said the Frenchman. "It's unbelievable because he's had two surgeries in the same season. He just came back, he played seven games and he's out again." Debuchy has played just 14 times since signing from Newcastle in July in a deal worth a reported £12m. With Kieran Gibbs recovering from an inflamed heel, 19-year-old Hector Bellerin or Calum Chambers may deputise against Manchester City on Sunday. original:
Meanwhile, Burundian police said they had arrested two foreign journalists who were reporting on armed groups. Violence in the country began last April, when President Pierre Nkurunziza announced his controversial bid for a third term. This sparked a series of protests and a failed coup attempt, leading to the death of over 400 people and displacing more than 240,000.

These arrests mark a deepening crisis for freedom of press in Burundi, a nation already beleaguered with political and societal unrest. The journalists, whose identities have not yet been released, were reportedly taken into custody while on assignment, capturing the turbulent situation in the capital, Bujumbura.

International press groups and human rights organizations have protested against the arrests, calling for the immediate release of the journalists and urging the Burundian government to respect press freedom and human rights. The arrest of journalists not only undermines the principles of free press, but also obstructs the world's understanding of the crises that Burundi

original: Rachel Miller has paid "brokers" up to Â£7,500 a time to free sex slaves. She travelled to parts of southern Turkey this summer that the Foreign Office had declared no-go zones. But the recent coup attempt in Turkey means she cannot work "under the radar" any longer, she said. Ms Miller, 40, a mother-of-three from Cinderhill in Nottingham, said her Kurdish husband supported her work but she did not always tell him the full story until after she had returned. "I don't deal directly with the slavers - but I deal with a broker who has contacted a family that wants to free their child from slavery," she said. "He says I can get your daughter but it will cost - it can cost up to $10,000." Her husband often stays in Britain with their two young children, who are seven and eight years old, while she makes her trips abroad. She said she would not be returning to Turkey in
